Enterprise Library 2.0 : Used by ASP.NET Applications on Shared Server?

Posted by davidhayden on February 6, 2006

Someone asked me this weekend if he could deploy Enterprise Library 2.0 for use with asp.net applications deployed on a shared server using a 3rd party host.  I have actually never tried it and couldn’t find an answer - although I found the question asked and gone unanswered in at least 1 place.


I guess the real question is whether or not you can xcopy Enterprise Library 2.0 assemblies referenced in your web apps up to 3rd party hosts?


I decided to try and use the Enterprise Library 2.0 Data Access Application Block on a 3rd party host this weekend and it appeared to work okay for at least a simple ExecuteDataSet() call.  When using DAAB, the following assemblies are copied to the shared server:



  • Common

  • Data

  • ObjectBuilder

 


I ran out of time before I could try it with the Logging Application Block, but I will play with it later in the week.


In the meantime, I would love to hear from others who may have tried this or know firsthand.  Can you use Enterprise Library 2.0 in asp.net applications on shared servers?  My guess is that the Data Access Application Block and the Logging Application Block would probably be the most popular for ASP.NET.


Thanks…

Enterprise Library 2.0 Plays Fine on ASP.NET Shared Servers →

4 Responses to Enterprise Library 2.0 : Used by ASP.NET Applications on Shared Server?

  1. dhayden says:
    February 7, 2006 at 5:44 pm

    I received an answer from the GDN Message board that you can use Enterprise Library 2.0 on a shared ASP.NET Server.

    “Hello,

    Yes, you can just copy the required .dlls and everything works ok. When you add EntLib references to your project it should add the required files to the bin directory. Then you can just copy your project to your production site and everything should work ok.

    If you’re using EntLib 1.x you will need to recompile the source project with the instumentation turned off to prevent the Instrumentation portion from being required to run. If you you’re using EntLib 2.x then Insturmentation is off by default.

    Hope this helps.

    -Phil

    PS – Here’s some information on deploying EntLib 1.x (including when/if you need to turn off instrumentation).
    http://blogs.msdn.com/tomholl/archive/2005/02/18/376187.aspx ”

    Hope this helps.

    Dave

  2. dhayden says:
    February 7, 2006 at 2:55 pm

    If instrumentation is the only issue, that is good news.

    I just asked the question again in the Enterprise Library Forums to see if anyone can enlighten us. If I get an answer, I will add it in a comment.

  3. JuanBarbatos says:
    February 6, 2006 at 8:28 pm

    I think the issue may have been with the instrumentation portion of the code (which was enabled by default under v1.0). On a webserver you may not have rights to install what it needed. I think that has been modified in the 2.0 version of code, but also have not had a chance to play around with it.

    On a side note I think I’ve seen the DAAB used in that manner though, I just forget where.

  4. Fregas says:
    February 6, 2006 at 7:46 pm

    my last experience with enterprise library is you could NOT do an xcopy. You had to install it on the server. I think it had some dependencies on COM or something.
